title: Suzi Quatro on Prince Charles telling her she had 'best legs since Tina Turner'
text:

Suzi Quatro is a raunchy catsuited rocker as she pounds out hits on her low-slung bass.

But put her in front of a royal and it is a different matter.

The world’s first female rock megastar is now a 69-year-old grandmother but is still ­“shaking her ass” and happy to talk about sex and drugs and rock ’n’ roll.

Suzi, who had massive hits in the 70s with Can the Can and Devil Gate Drive, rewrote rock’s rulebook for girls. She counts fellow legends Iggy Pop, Debbie Harry and Alice Cooper as close friends.

And while many older rock stars have called it a day, Suzi, whose on-stage leather outfits were inspired by Elvis, is still going strong after more than five decades on the road and 55 million-plus record sales.

Yet it is a royal encounter that is ­uppermost in her mind when we talk to her in a swanky lounge of London’s Hard Rock Hotel. She met Prince Charles at a Prince’s Trust event in the mid 80s and it turned out he was a big fan.

(Image: Tim Merry)

Suzi chuckled as she recalled her ­encounter with her unlikely admirer.

She said: “He was meeting all the ­performers, and while walking past me he said loudly, ‘You have the best legs since Tina Turner.’

“I was speechless – my jaw fell open. I should have said ‘thank you,’ but I froze. It was an honour but I handled it like a bumbling idiot.”

The feisty star has not always been so retiring. She once threw old pal Iggy Pop out of one of her gigs.

She said: “I thought we were going to jam but he was out of it and started going crazy. I had to have him removed because he was being so nutty. I’m sure he forgives me, though.”

(Image: Mirrorpix)

Suzi does not think of herself as a hell-raiser and has never taken drugs. .

She said: “I’m really square – my husband calls me the ‘mild one’, not the ‘wild one’.

“We’d drink, play poker and dance but I was too much my mother’s daughter to go off the rails.”

But she did trash a hotel room.

She recalled: “It was the end of a seven-month tour, and everybody went nuts. I cut open my pillow and snowed everyone with feathers and we blew up a TV.”

And then there was the time she shot Alice Cooper in the face. Alice, now 71, and Suzi were having a fight with dart guns in a hotel.

(Image: Daily Record)

She said: “He peeked out from behind a TV, my arrow hit him between the eyes. He said his first thought was, ‘good shot’, and the next was, ‘ouch’.” Suzi’s hot stage image was not intentional but did attract unwelcome ­attention from men. She said: “It was never about being sexy. I just thought a tight suit would hold everything in one place.

“During one gig a guy was making rude gestures with his tongue.

“So I moved over, swung my guitar and whacked him on the head. I made it look like part of the show. He was disgusting – but he paid the price.”

Such a gutsy ­nature helped Suzi cope in the male-dominated world of rock.

(Image: REX/Shutterstock)

She said: “My attitude was, ‘I’m a bass player. Do you have a problem with that?’ It won me respect, but even to this day, if somebody p**ses me off, I’ll be like, ‘Don’t f**k with me.’”

Today she believes singers’ attitudes have changed for the worse.

“Now it’s like, ‘how many clothes can you take off?’ I don’t like it. We have this #MeToo movement but women go on stage ­embarrassingly naked. How does that make sense?” On the subject of #MeToo – sparked by sexual assault claims against film producer Harvey Weinstein – Suzi’s views are ­surprisingly blunt.

She said: “If I was an actress and had a work meeting with a producer in his room, that would ring a warning bell.

“And if he then walked out of his bathroom in a ­bathrobe… would any ­woman with half a brain stay?” Suzi insisted it’s “an entirely different matter” if there is a sexual assault.

She said: “They should be strung up by their balls. But don’t put yourself in stupid ­situations. I’m all for empowering women and equality but don’t be dumb.”

New docu-film Suzi Q charts the ­trailblazer’s rise to the top after she started a band with her sisters called the Pleasure Seekers aged just 14.

She struggled to get a record deal after moving from Detroit to London in 1971 but her eventual breakthrough produced massive hits with memorable TV ­appearances on Top of the Pops.

(Image: Getty)

Essex-based Suzi married her lead guitarist, Len Tuckey, in 1976. They had two kids, Laura, now 37, and Richard, 34, who she always took on tour with her as youngsters.

She said: “I had to take fertility drugs to have them and I didn’t go through two ­caesareans just to leave them at home.” Suzi once spoke of her anguish over having an abortion, aged 18, following a fling with a record exec, but said: “I have only one regret in life, and that’s the fact I didn’t go back to the States to see my mother in the last week of her life.

“My producer said, ‘Don’t go – you can’t handle it.’ And I thought, ‘Maybe he’s right.’ But in all honesty if I had that choice again, I would go.”

After splitting from Len she wed tour promoter Rainer Hass in 1993 – but they have never lived together in 26 years. “We go back and forth between the UK and his home in Germany. It keeps the romance fresh and I like my own company.”

(Image: Getty)

Suzi’s not worried about ageing and has no interest in plastic surgery.

She said: “I embrace ageing. You can’t reverse the process. We’re all going to get old. So many people look like they saw the same doctor. I don’t like that.”

So does she have to work out to squeeze into those catsuits? She said: “I don’t need one.

"On stage I wear a heavy guitar under hot lights, and I’m basically ­jogging, singing and playing for two hours. No gym workout can do that.”

Suzi once won Rear of the Year – and she rubbishes claims that is sexist. She said: “I’m proud. If you have a nice ass, so what? Political correctness is stupid.

“I’ve always had a good backside, and I’m still shaking it at 69.” As well as bossing it on stage, Suzi memorably starred in US sitcom Happy Days as the sister of Fonzie, played by Henry Winkler.

She is still good pals with Winkler and said: “I love him – he gave me plenty of clues on set. He’s intelligent and could have been a great ­politician.” Suzi would like to act more and be on Strictly Come Dancing .

But she has turned down I’m A Celeb at least nine times. One thing is for ­certain, Suzi has no ­retirement plan. She said: “My dad worked until he was 89, so I’m still a baby. I’ve got 20 years in me yet.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: The world’s first female rock megastar is now a 69-year-old grandmother but is still ­“shaking her ass” and happy to talk about sex and drugs and rock ’n’ roll
